Messages.Author: Tommaso Pincelli
Messages.Content: Dear students, exercise 6 might require further information to be completed effectively. First of all, it requires a good ODE solver, that is capable of handling variable step sizes to handle the many different timescales involved. This can be found, for example, in the "scipy" codebase among the "integrate" functions. I have used solve_ivp: from scipy.integrate import solve_ivp solve_ivp(rate_equations_function, solution_time_interval, initial_conditions_array, args=(params), method='LSODA', atol=1e-8, rtol=1e-6) where the method and tolerances have been chosen to reduce computation time. Secondly, the solutions are meant to be studied considering the initial conditions N1(0)=0 N2(0)=0 with the pumping rate being switched on at t=0 and off after the mandated times. It can be helpful to use an interactive slider to explore the values of the pumping rates (N.B. you have to span several orders of magnitude so a logarithmic slider can be more convenient). Best regards, Tommaso

Discussions.Discussion_Name: Useful resource for HHG and Exercise 5

Messages.Author: Tommaso Pincelli
Messages.Content: Dear students, as mentioned in the last exercise class, a useful reference for HHG (not covered in the Saleh, Teich, Fundamentals of Photonics) are the lecture notes by Thierry Ruchon of the CEA-LIDYL Saclay, which you can find at this link: Lecture Ruchon. ATTENTION: These notes are written with a very didactic structure to introduce newcomers to the topic, but cover HHG and attosecond physics in much more detail than what has been done in class. In the oral examination, you will only be asked about what the professor has discussed in his slides. If you use formulas and expressions from this, do so with EXTREME CAUTION, as they are in atomic units where many constants are set to 1.
